title: MEGA DPDT Switch - Tank Style
materials_required: Tabs of iron plate about 1" x 4" about 1/4" thick
Piece of plywood 3/8" thick and at least 8" x 5"
Length of 3/8" steel rod about 7-8" long
Small tube of 2 part 5 minute epoxy
description: This project details how to build a MEGA DPDT (double pole - double throw) switch in a tank style, which can be used for reversing polarity and is particularly useful for controlling motors in robots, animatronics, and other similar applications. The switch is designed to be robust and have a substantial feel.
steps: Gather all the required parts and tools as listed in the materials section.
Drill two mounting holes in the iron tabs. Then attach each tab to one leaf of the hinges by either drilling holes and bolting them together or by welding them.
Prepare the steel rod by grinding down or flattening the last 3 inches on one end to create a flat surface. Drill two holes in this flattened section.
Cut the 1/4" plywood into squares and sand them smooth. Attach the chosen handle to the prepared steel rod using welding or epoxy.

Attach the steel rod to the plywood square by applying epoxy and screwing it in place. Then, apply epoxy fillets and attach the hinge tabs to the plywood square, ensuring the tabs and rod do not touch.
Prepare the plywood panel for mounting the switch. Plan the placement of the switch(es) according to the intended use.
Temporarily screw the hinged section to the plywood panel. Move the handle back and forth to determine the placement of the large bolts that will make contact with the metal tabs.
Mark and drill holes for the large bolts, ensuring a tight fit.
Unscrew the switch handle and drill holes in the screw marks for the smaller bolts. Drill holes where you marked for the larger bolts.
Reinstall everything and bolt down tightly. Adjust the large bolts so the tabs make contact on both bolts simultaneously.
Wire up the switch by clamping stripped wires between two of the nuts on the bottom of the switch. Refer to a wiring diagram for clarity and ensure proper polarity.
Mount and use the switch as needed, such as in a control panel for a robot or other motorized device. Exercise caution when wiring and using the switch, especially with higher voltages.
